title-group.subtitle: The Role of Work Interruptions and Supportive Employers

article-meta.aff: 1University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USA

author-notes.corresp: Jeungkun Kim, Samsung Economic Research Institute, Seocho 2-dong, Seocho-gu, Seoul 137-955, Korea. Email: jkun.kim@samsung.com

abstract.p: This study investigates pathways by which employed caregivers’ stress is related to their work performance appraisal, with particular attention to work interruptions and supportive employers. Based on a nationally representative sample from the 2004 National Long-Term Care Survey (NLTCS), the study focuses on caregivers to older adults who are currently participating in paid employment (N = 652). Results from structural equation modeling indicate that work interruptions mediate the relationship between caregivers’ stress and their work performance appraisal. In addition, the support of employers moderates the relationship between employed caregivers’ stress and their work interruptions as well as the relationship between their work interruptions and work performance appraisal. These results point to the need for training supervisors and helping them to understand the potential dual effects of their support on employed caregivers’ work interruptions and performance.

body.p: As more women participate in paid jobs and more men share family responsibilities with women, there has been an increasing number of workers who must combine work with family responsibilities (Bond, Galinsky, & Swanberg, 1998; Kossek, 2005). Such changes in the demographic complexion of employment have had repercussions on the proportion of individuals who are undertaking both work and eldercare responsibilities (Sterns, Barrett, Czaja, & Barr, 1994). The resulting conflict between their work and caregiving responsibilities may influence employees’ work attendance as well as their job performance (Eby, Casper, Lockwood, Bordeaux, & Brinley, 2005; Hammer, Bauer, & Grandey, 2003). Increasingly, to address the negative effects of these dual responsibilities, employers are providing supportive programs and services to their employees (Breaugh & Frye, 2008; Kossek & Nichol, 1992).

To date, however, most efforts to enhance employees’ abilities to balance their work and family responsibilities have focused on two particular areas. One major effort has focused on support to those who have childcare responsibilities (Neal, Chapman, Ingersoll-Dayton, & Emlen, 1993; Neal & Hammer, 2007). Although older persons make up a growing proportion of the general population (OECD, 2006) and there are increasing numbers of employees who take care of older adults with long-term care needs (Neal & Wagner, 2001), there remains a limited awareness of employees’ eldercare responsibilities, compared with employees’ childcare responsibilities. Therefore, support programs for employees with eldercare responsibilities are not as common as support programs for employees with childcare responsibilities, although employees caring for the elderly are more likely to be interrupted at work than those caring for children (Neal et al., 1993; Sahibzada, Hammer, Neal, & Kuang, 2005; Scott, Hwang, & Rogers, 2006).

A second effort has focused on formal support to employees with caregiving responsibilities (Neal & Wagner, 2001; Potter, Churilla, & Smith, 2006; Thompson, Beauvais, & Lyness, 1999). Formal workplace supports include policies (e.g., flexible work arrangements), benefits (e.g., dependent-care tax credits), and services (e.g., resources and referral services), which are designed to diminish difficulties in managing dual roles (Neal & Hammer, 2007). Although formal support can help employed caregivers to balance work and caregiving responsibilities (Lechner & Gupta, 1996), its availability does not remove some important barriers that can prevent employees from successfully using formal support (Allen, 2001). For example, if employers and supervisors do not encourage the use of formal support programs, employed caregivers are hesitant to use them; they worry that making use of these formal benefits may jeopardize their careers (Morris, 1997; Sahibzada et al., 2005).

Several studies suggest that informal support, such as supervisor or employer support and a family supportive culture at work, may play an important role in determining whether or not employed caregivers use formal supports and whether use of these formal supports addresses the concerns of employees with work and family responsibilities (Hammer, Colton, Caubet, & Brockwood, 2002; Lobel & Kossek, 1996; Mesemer-Eagnus & Viswesvaran, 2006). Despite the probable importance of informal support, relatively few studies have examined the effects of informal support at the workplace. Those that have conducted such research have been limited by restricted samples (e.g., employees from specific geographical areas and specific types of organizations) thus reducing the generalizability of their findings (Atienza & Stephens, 2000; Sahibzada et al., 2005).

To expand the scope of research on balancing work and family responsibilities, this study uses a nationally representative sample and focuses on informal eldercare support by employers. We focus on informal support because this form of support may be more likely than formal eldercare policies to impact employed caregivers’ ability to balance work and eldercare responsibilities as well as their work performance (Scharlach, Lowe, & Schneider, 1991). In so doing, we examine the extent to which one kind of informal support (i.e., having an understanding employer) influences the relationships among caregiver stress, work interruptions, and work performance appraisal.

sec.title: Conceptual Framework
sec.p: Our study builds on a conceptual framework that examines the relationships among caregiving demands, support at work, stress, and work interruptions (Neal et al., 1993). In the model developed by Neal and colleagues, work and family demands influence stress and work interruptions directly and indirectly through support at work. We extend their framework to include employed caregivers’ work performance appraisal and to consider the mechanisms that may influence the impact of employed caregivers’ stress on their work performance appraisal. As shown in Figure 1, our adaptation of the framework developed by Neal and colleagues examines the relationships among caregivers’ demands, stress, support at work (i.e., supportive employers), work interruptions, and work performance appraisal. This study investigates three key relationships: (a) the relationships between the demands of employees with eldercare responsibilities and their stress level, (b) the mediating effects of work interruptions on the relationship between employed elder caregivers’ stress and work performance appraisal, and (c) the moderating effects of supportive employers on two distinct relationships: between employed elder caregivers’ stress and their work interruptions and between work interruptions and work performance appraisal.

To address the first set of relationships, this study examines the demands of employed elder caregivers that contribute to their stress level. Because employed caregivers are likely to experience stress as they juggle eldercare and work responsibilities, it is important to understand the predictors of employed caregivers’ stress.

The second set of hypothesized relationships focuses on the indirect (i.e., mediating) effect of work interruptions on the relationship between employed caregivers’ stress and their work performance appraisal as well as the direct effect of employed caregivers’ stress on their work performance appraisal. In particular, we are exploring the extent to which employees who are experiencing caregiver stress may also experience more work interruptions such as making or receiving phone calls related to eldercare, missing days at work, and worrying about their care recipients while at work. These work interruptions may then contribute to employees’ perception that their work performance is inadequate. Previous studies provide some support for these hypothesized pathways by showing that employees with caregiving responsibilities are more likely to have high levels of stress and are, therefore, more likely to miss days at work and to receive frequent calls than their counterparts without caregiving responsibilities (Lee, Walker, & Shoup, 2001; Neal & Wagner, 2001).

As for the third set of hypothesized relationships, our work highlights the moderating effects of informal support at the workplace. That is, when employers are understanding, it may enable employees who experience work interruptions to view their own work performance more positively than do employees whose supervisors are not aware of or understanding about their caregiving situation. In this way, the informal support from employers may interact with employed caregiver stress to influence work interruptions, and this informal support may also interact with work interruptions to influence work performance appraisal.

As shown in Figure 1, we examine a conceptual model in which employed caregivers’ stress is associated with their work performance appraisal both directly and indirectly through employees’ work interruptions and, in turn, their work interruptions are related to employed caregivers’ appraisal of their own job performance. In the following section, we present the empirical research that provides support for these hypothesized pathways.

sec.title: Employed Caregivers’ Demands and Their Caregiving Stress
sec.p: There is considerable evidence that employed caregivers’ demands are positively related to their stress level (Kramer & Kipnis, 1995; Lee et al., 2001; Scharlach & Boyd, 1989). One important set of demands for caregivers is the impairment level of their care recipients (Ingersoll-Dayton & Raschick, 2004; Schulz, O’Brien, Bookwala, & Fleissner, 1995; Starrels, Ingersoll-Dayton, Dowler, & Neal, 1997). Some researchers have found that care recipients’ impairment has a positive association with caregivers’ stress levels (Gottlieb, Kelloway, & Fraboni, 1994; Ingersoll-Dayton & Raschick, 2004; Pinquart & Sorensen, 2003). Second, caregivers’ demands include their own employment situation. The number of hours of employment has been associated with greater stress among employed caregivers (Neal et al., 1993). In addition, another important demand to consider is the caregivers’ own health status because it is a predictor of caregiving stress (Lawton, Moss, Kleban, Glickman, & Rovine, 1991; Lecovich, 2008; Mui & Morrow-Howell, 1993).

Finally, demands of the caregiving situation include the extent to which caregivers have or do not have resources that enable them to provide care (Pearlin, Mullan, Semple, & Skaff, 1990; Starrels et al., 1997). Krause (1997) as well as Wethington and Kessler (1986) have suggested that back-up helpers (i.e., those who would provide caregiving assistance when needed) play an important role in decreasing stress levels. When employed caregivers do not have back-up helpers, they may experience a higher degree of stress. Given these previous results, this study poses the following hypothesis.

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1: Caregiving demands (including characteristics of care recipients, caregivers, and the caregiving situation) are positively related to employed caregivers’ stress.

sec.title: Employed Caregivers’ Stress, Work Interruptions, and Work Performance Appraisal
sec.p: Most research has focused on the direct effect of employed caregivers’ stress on work performance. Wagner and Neal (1994), Scott and colleagues (2006), and Sherman and Reed (2008) demonstrated that stress from work and eldercare responsibilities was related to decreased work performance. Meiner and Lueckenotte (2005) reported that 67% of employed caregivers experienced difficulties in balancing work and caregiving that resulted in decreased work productivity.

Our work builds on this previous research by examining one of the mechanisms by which caregiver stress influences caregivers’ performance at work. Specifically, we are exploring the role of work interruptions. When exhausted by caregiving and feeling overwhelmed, it is likely that caregiving stress will spill over into the workplace (Neal et al., 1993; Thoits, 1995). Caregivers who are experiencing stress and are unable to complete their responsibilities at home may need to use work time to attend to caregiving concerns and obligations (Shoptaugh, Phelps, & Visio, 2004). One way in which caregiver stress can spill over to work is via interruptions while at work. Several studies have found that employed caregivers experience a variety of work interruptions related to their caregiving responsibilities such as missing time at work, receiving phone calls related to eldercare, and worrying about care recipients while at work (Cullen, Hammer, Neal, & Sinclair, 2009; Scharlach & Boyd, 1989; Stephens & Christianson, 1986). Such work interruptions are likely to affect, in turn, caregivers’ ability to perform well at work. We are exploring the extent to which such work interruptions may account for the relationship between caregiver stress and their poor work performance.
In the present study, we examine both the direct and indirect effects of caregiver stress on work performance appraisal via work interruptions. In so doing, we propose the following hypothesis:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 2: Work interruptions have a mediating effect on the relationship between employed caregivers’ stress and their work performance appraisal.

sec.title: The Role of Supportive Employers in the Relationship Between Caregivers’ Stress and Work Performance Appraisal
sec.p: Although underexplored, informal support at the workplace may play a key role in helping caregivers perform well at work despite the stress they are experiencing as caregivers. A few studies have reported that supportive employers may provide a more flexible environment at work that allows employees to interrupt their work to address their family responsibilities (Eaton, 1999; Mennino, Rubin, & Brayﬁeld, 2005). For example, Eaton (1999) observed that informal support from supervisors or employers can enhance employees’ work flexibility (e.g., allowing for time off from work). Under such conditions, employees with caregiving responsibilities may feel more free to interrupt work (e.g., to take time off to meet their caregiving obligations) if their supervisors or employers understand their caregiving demands. Thus the following hypothesis is posed:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 3: For employees whose employers support their caregiving responsibilities, the effect of stress on work interruptions is stronger than when employers are not supportive.

sec.p: The extent to which employers are supportive of their employees’ caregiving demands may also influence the way in which work interruptions are related to work performance. A meta-analysis conducted by Riggle, Edmonson, and Hansen (2008) found that employees who felt that their organizations provided high levels of support were more likely to have better work performance as compared to their counterparts who felt that their organizations provided low levels of support. Applying the results of this meta-analysis to the context of balancing work and family suggests that caregiving employees who feel understood by their employers will perceive work interruptions as more legitimate and that the negative effect of work interruptions on appraised work performance will be reduced. We, therefore, propose the following hypothesis:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 4: For employees whose employers support their caregiving responsibilities, the negative effect of work interruptions on work performance appraisal is less strong than when employers are not supportive.

sec.p: Using the adapted conceptual framework developed by Neal and colleagues (1993), the present study adds to the existing literature on employed caregiver stress in two important ways. First, we consider the mediating effect of work interruptions between caregiver stress and work performance appraisal. Second, this study focuses on the role of the supportive employer and analyzes the extent to which the relationship between employed caregivers’ stress and their work performance appraisal is moderated by employers’ informal support.

sec.title: Sample
sec.p: This study is based on the National Long-Term Care Survey (NLTCS) interviews that were conducted in 2004. The NLTCS includes a nationally representative sample of older adults age 65 and above who were selected from Medicare beneficiary enrollment files. The NLTCS was first conducted in 1982 and then follow-up surveys were conducted in 1984, 1989, 1994, 1999, and 2004. This study used data from the most recent 2004 survey to complete the first step in testing the adapted conceptual framework (Neal et al., 1993); that is, we focused on examining the relationships among the key variables from a cross-sectional perspective. The total sample size of the 2004 survey was 6,171 older adults who were divided into two groups: those living in the community and those living in institutions. Among older adults living in the community, 4,472 older adults had disabilities or health problems and received help from 2,303 unpaid informal caregivers. A total of 1,924 of these caregivers completed interviews and were involved in the 2004 NLTCS. Among these caregivers, this study focuses on those who were employed (N = 642). Thus, the study sample is employed caregivers who provided some type of assistance for an older adult who was chronically frail, ill, or disabled.

sec.title: Employed elder caregivers’ demands
sec.p: Caregivers’ demands were measured by four latent constructs: (a) care recipients’ impairment, (b) caregivers’ working hours, (c) back-up support availability, and (d) caregivers’ health status. Each latent construct was measured with a scale such that higher scores represented a more demanding caregiving situation. The first latent construct, care recipients’ impairment, was measured using two variables: activities of daily living (ADL) score and a total number of disruptive behaviors of the care recipient. To obtain an ADL score, caregivers were asked whether the care recipients had difficulty in each of six activities (0 = no, 1 = yes): walking, eating, getting in or out of bed, dressing, bathing, and toileting. The total ADL score represents the number of areas with which the older adult needs assistance for their routine daily activities. Disruptive behaviors was a composite score based on the caregivers’ assessment of the extent to which 15 care recipient behaviors were disruptive during the past week (0 = no days, 1 = 1-2 days, 2 = 3-4 days, 3 = 5 or more). Thus, a higher score indicates more care recipient disruptive behaviors. The second latent construct, caregivers’ working hours, was measured by the number of hours they were employed per week. To assess the third latent construct, back-up support availability, caregivers were asked the following question: “If you were unable to help [a care recipient], is there someone else who would do the things you do?” The resulting measure was scored dichotomously (0 = yes, 1 = no). The fourth latent construct, caregivers’ health status, was measured by a dichotomous variable (0 = good health, 1 = poor health) to obtain a clear distinction in health status.

sec.title: Employed caregivers’ stress
sec.p: Caregivers’ stress was measured by four items: (a) “You are exhausted when you go to bed at night”, (b) “You have more things to do than you can handle”, (c) “You don’t have time just for yourself”, and (d) “You work hard as a caregiver but never seem to make any progress” (1 = not at all, 2 = somewhat, 3 = quite a lot, 4 = completely). A higher score indicates more caregiver stress. These items were also used to measure caregivers’ stress in a previous study (Ingersoll-Dayton & Raschick, 2004).

sec.title: Employer support at the workplace
sec.p: Employer support at the workplace was measured by the caregivers’ response to the question, “How would you rate your employers’ attitude toward the demands of your caregiving: would you say they were very understanding, somewhat understanding, or not very understanding?” The responses were recoded and resulted in a dichotomous score (0 = not very understanding or unaware of it, 1 = very and somewhat understanding) so that we could compare the two groups of employers in our analyses. The definition of supportive employers in this study is consistent with that of previous studies (Behson, 2005; Mennino et al., 2005).

sec.title: Work interruptions
sec.p: Since employed caregivers of older adults take days off to provide help to their care recipients and check on them several times daily by telephone (Azarnoff & Scharlach, 1988), we attempted to capture these kinds of work interruptions in this study. Specifically, we used three variables that were based on the employed caregivers’ assessments of the occurrence of the following work interruptions during the previous 2 months: (a) “You have missed too many days,” (b) “Phone calls about or from a care recipient interrupt you,” and (c) “You worry about a care recipient while you are at work.” Each variable was scored dichotomously (0 = disagree, 1 = agree).

sec.title: Work performance appraisal
sec.p: The employed caregivers’ appraisal of their own work performance was measured by two items: (a) “You have been dissatisfied with the quality of your work” and (b) “You have had less energy for your work.” Each variable was scored dichotomously so that a higher score indicates better work performance appraisal (0 = yes, 1 = no).

sec.title: Analytical Method
sec.p: The data were first summarized using descriptive statistics and correlations. The main analytical method in this study was structural equation modeling (SEM) that includes both observed variables and latent constructs, and examines causal relationships among the variables. Using LISREL 8.7 (Jöreskog & Sörbom, 1993), we first estimated a measurement model to determine the relationships between observed variables and their latent constructs before identifying a structural model. As ordinal variables used in this study did not fulfill the assumption of a multivariate normal data distribution, we first normalized the variables. To compute the normal scores for the ordinal variables, we used the Normal Scores option on the Statistics menu in PRELIS (Jöreskog & Sörbom, 1999). After normalizing those variables, this study employed a Maximum Likelihood (ML) estimator and estimated the relationships between observed variables and their latent constructs.

To evaluate the fit of the models, this study employed chi-square analyses and four goodness-of-fit-indices: the Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA), the Goodness-of-Fit-Index (GFI), the Comparative Fit Index (CFI), and the Normed Fit Index (NFI; Bentler, 1990; Bentler & Bonett, 1980; Browne & Cudeck, 1993; Jöreskog & Sörbom, 1993; Steiger, 1990). A good fit is achieved if the chi-square statistic is not significant, the value of RMSEA is less than 0.05 and for the other indices, a value that exceeds 0.95 is considered to be an acceptable fit (Green, Camilli, & Elmore, 2006). Because the chi-square statistic is sensitive to sample size, especially if the sample size is more than 200 or less than 100, we did not rely on this statistic as the primary indicator of model fit (Hair, Anderson, Tatham, & Black, 1998; Jöreskog & Sörbom, 1993; Tanaka, 1987).

To test for the mediating effect of work interruptions, we compared the direct and indirect effects between employed caregivers’ stress and work performance appraisal, using significance tests, which LISREL provides (MacKinnon, 2008). In particular, mediating effects are indicated when the indirect effects are statistically significant. To test for the moderating effects of supportive employers, we assessed the same model within two subgroups: employed caregivers with supportive employers versus employed caregivers without supportive employers. We tested whether or not path coefficients between (a) employed caregivers’ stress and work interruptions and (b) work interruptions and work performance appraisal differed between the two groups, using a chi-square difference test (Bollen, 1989; Kline, 1998).

To investigate the moderating effects of supportive employers in the relationships among the three latent constructs (employed caregivers’ stress, work interruptions, and work performance appraisal), we conducted subgroup analyses. That is, after each of the path coefficients and factor loadings was first constrained to be equal across the two groups (i.e., employed caregivers with and without supportive employers), the constrained model was compared to the model that allowed the path coefficients among the three latent constructs to vary as a function of a supportive employer. If the χ2 difference between the two models is significant, the model without the constraints fits better than the model that constrained the relationships among the three latent constructs, indicating that there is a significant interaction effect of a supportive employer.

sec.title: Descriptive Analysis
sec.p: The means, standard deviations, and correlations among all the variables in this model are presented in Table 1. The average ADL score of care recipients was 1.0 out of 6 (SD =1.7) and the average score for disruptive behaviors was 4.2 out of 26 (SD = 5.3). The average working hours of caregivers was 37 hours a week and 72% of caregivers had a back-up helper for their care recipients, whereas 77% of caregivers answered that their employers understood their caregiving demands. Most (84%) of them reported that their health status was either good or excellent.

caption.p: Means, Standard Deviation, and Correlations of Study Variables.

fn.p: Note. Disruptive behavior = total number of disruptive behaviors of a care recipient, CGPoorHealth = caregivers’ poor health status, CGWorkHour = number of hours caregivers are employed per week, No helper = caregivers’ back-up support, Stress 1 = exhausted, Stress 2 =more to do than can handle, Stress 3 = no time for self, Stress 4 = work hard, no progress, Supportive = employers’ support at the workplace, Frequent calls = frequent calls from a care recipient, Missing days = Missing days by caregiving, Less energy = less energy at the work place, Worry = worry about a care recipient at work, Dissatisfaction = dissatisfied with the quality of work.

sec.title: Structural Equation Models
sec.p: After the confirmatory factor analysis confirmed a relationship between the observed variables and latent constructs (RMSEA = .033, NFI = .99, CFI = 1.0, GFI = .91, and χ2 (df = 24) = 39.49 with p = .024; not shown here), we tested the overall hypothesized model. The results of the structural equation parameter estimation, in Figure 2, show the standardized path coefficients representing the relationships among employed caregivers’ demands, employed caregivers’ stress, work interruptions, and work performance appraisal. Coefficients are standardized betas, or standardized lambdas. The fit indices provide strong support for the hypothesized model: NFI = .96, CFI = .98, GFI = .96, RMSEA = .047 and χ2 (df = 67) = 151.67 (p < .001).

caption.p: Results of structural equation modeling for all employed caregivers.

Note. Coefficients are standardized betas, or standardized lambdas. All the paths in solid lines are statistically significant at *p < .05, **p < .01, or ***p < .001 while dotted lines are not statistically significant.

sec.title: The Effects of Employed Caregivers’ Demands on Caregiving Stress
sec.p: With regard to the first hypothesis concerning the relationship between employed caregivers’ demands and their caregiving stress, two of the caregiver demands (i.e., caregivers’ working hours and care recipients’ impairment) are significantly associated with employed caregivers’ stress. As shown in Figure 2, care recipients’ impairment is positively associated (β = .77, p < .001) with employed caregivers’ stress. Caregivers who work more hours are more likely to have higher levels of stress than those who work fewer hours (β = .11, p < .05). The effects of having a back-up helper and the caregivers’ health status on their stress levels are not statistically significant. Therefore, the first hypothesis is partially supported.

sec.title: The Mediating Effects of Work Interruptions
sec.p: The second hypothesis concerning the mediating effects of work interruptions between employed caregivers’ stress and their work performance appraisal is also supported. As shown in Figure 2, although the direct effect of employed caregivers’ stress on work performance appraisal is not statistically significant (β = –.16, p > .05), the indirect effect through work interruptions is statistically significant (β = –.52, p < .001, not shown here). This indirect effect is computed by multiplying the standardized effect (β = .66, p < .001) of employed caregivers’ stress on work interruptions by the standardized effect (β = –.79, p < .01) of employed caregivers’ stress on work performance appraisal.

The finding that the indirect effect is statistically significant indicates that work interruptions mediate the relationship between employed caregivers’ stress and their work performance appraisal. Specifically, when employed caregivers experience stress, they tend to have more work interruptions and when work interruptions increase, employed caregivers’ work performance appraisals tend to decrease.

sec.title: The Moderating Effects of Supportive Employers
sec.p: We used a multigroup invariance procedure to test the third and fourth hypotheses that focus on the moderating effect of supportive employers. Due to missing data in 22 cases with regard to supportiveness of employer, the total sample size for the analysis was 620. After fitting the model for the total sample, as described above, we conducted two subgroup analyses using the same model. One is for employed caregivers with a supportive employer (N = 478) and the other for employed caregivers without a supportive employer (N = 142).

To determine whether the relationships among employed caregivers’ stress, work interruptions, and work performance appraisal are significantly different across the two groups, we conducted the chi-square difference test by comparing the constrained model to the model without constraints. The constrained model across the two groups results in the following fit indices: NFI = .93, CFI = .97, GFI = .86, RMSEA = .047 and χ2 (df = 172) = 280.38 (p < .001). Allowing the paths among the three latent constructs to be free, while constraining the remaining paths and factor loadings to be equal across the two groups, results in a good fit (NFI = .93, CFI = .97, GFI = .96, RMSEA = .045 and χ2 (df = 169) = 269.041 with p < .001). When the model without the constraints is compared with the constrained model, we find that the difference in χ2 is significant, Δχ2 (3) =11.34 (p < .05). The results show that the path coefficients among the three latent variables (employed caregivers’ stress, work interruptions, and work performance appraisal) are significantly different across the two groups (i.e., employed caregivers with a supportive employer and employed caregivers without a supportive employer).

Thus, the third hypothesis which focuses on the moderating role of supportive employers on the relationship between employed caregivers’ stress and work interruptions and between work interruptions and work performance appraisal is supported. Specifically, the relationship between employed caregivers’ stress and their work interruptions is significantly stronger for employed caregivers with supportive employers (β = .68, p < .001) than for employed caregivers without supportive employers (β = .30, p < .001) as shown in Figure 3. This finding indicates that employed caregivers with supportive employers are more likely than those without supportive employers to miss days, make frequent calls, and to worry about care recipients at work when their stress increases.

caption.p: Results of structural equation modeling by two subgroups: Employed caregivers with supportive employers versus without supportive employers.

Note. Coefficients are standardized. All the paths in solid lines are statistically significant at *p < .05, **p < .01, or ***p < .001 while dotted lines are not statistically significant. Numbers without parentheses indicate standardized coefficients of employed caregivers with supportive employers while numbers within parentheses indicate standardized coefficients of employed caregivers without supportive employers. Factor loadings between observed variables and latent constructs are constrained to be equal across groups; therefore, the rest of the model is omitted in this figure.

sec.p: The fourth hypothesis pertaining to the moderating role of supportive employers on the relationship between work interruptions and work performance appraisal is also supported. That is, the negative relationship between employed caregivers’ work interruptions and their work performance appraisal is weaker for employed caregivers with supportive employers (β = –.73, p < .01) than for employed caregivers without supportive employers (β = –.91, p < .001). This finding indicates that support from employers (i.e., understanding the demands of the employee’s caregiving situation) is associated with a reduction in the negative effects of work interruptions on employed caregivers’ appraisals of their work performance.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our study confirms the utility of our model that expanded the conceptual framework developed by Neal and colleagues (1993). By building on their previous work, this research highlights the pathways between employed caregivers’ stress and their work performance appraisal. We found that poorer health of care recipients and more hours of work are related to employed caregivers’ stress. These results show that employed caregivers’ demands are predictors of their stress. Specifically, consistent with previous studies, the demands associated with caregivers stress were care recipients’ impairments (Lee et al., 2001; Starrels et al., 1997) and caregivers’ hours of work (Neal et al., 1993). Furthermore, employed caregivers’ stress is indirectly related to their work performance appraisal through their experiences of work interruptions. That is, stress is associated with work interruptions which, in turn, are related to poorer work performance appraisal. In addition, we found that the relationship between employed caregivers’ stress and their work performance appraisal is also associated with an employer’s informal support.

One of our key findings is that work interruptions play an important role in the relationship between employed caregivers’ stress and their work performance appraisal. Although we hypothesized that employed caregivers’ stress would have both a direct and an indirect effect on their work performance appraisal, only the indirect effect was statistically significant. This means that work interruptions play a critical role in mediating the relationship between stress and work performance appraisal. The high level of employed caregivers’ stress is associated with work interruptions which, in turn, are related to their poor work performance appraisal. Whereas others (Reid, Stajduhar, & Chappell, 2010) have identified work interruptions as common among employed caregivers, our work has taken this finding a step further. Specifically, we find that work interruptions contribute to employees’ feeling that their work is inadequate. Taken together, work interruptions appear to be a key mechanism for explaining how employed caregivers’ stress is associated with their work performance appraisal.

A second key finding is that employers play a role in helping employees adapt to their dual caregiving and work responsibilities. Consistent with Eaton (1999), these results demonstrate that when employed caregivers feel understood by employers, the employed caregivers are more likely to interrupt their work to address caregiving responsibilities. This study finding suggests that employees feel more free to interrupt their work (e.g., to take time off to meet their caregiving obligations) if their employers or supervisors understand the demands of their elder caregiving situation. It may be that when employers are supportive of employees’ caregiving responsibilities, employed caregivers anticipate fewer penalties if they attend to these responsibilities while at work and are therefore more likely to interrupt their work to focus on caregiving.

Another significant discovery is that when employers understand employees’ elder caregiving situations, employees are less likely to feel that their caregiving-related work interruptions are negatively related to their work performance. This finding along with those of other researchers (Allen, 2001; Eaton, 2003; Thompson et al., 1999) highlights the potential impact of informal support in the workplace on work performance. It is possible that the negative effects of work interruptions on work performance are mitigated by the positive effects of supportiveness of employers or supervisors on employees’ job commitment and job satisfaction (Thomas & Ganster, 1995). Furthermore, as Eaton (2003) and Hill, Hawkins, Ferris, & Weitzman (2001) suggested, support from employers increases the flexibility and autonomy of employed caregivers at the workplace and ultimately improves their productivity, thereby diminishing the negative effects of work interruptions on work performance.

Our study has implications for the workplace. It is important that employers understand the caregiving responsibilities of their employees and that they convey support to them. Feeling supported by their employers is associated, as we found, with employees feeling less self-critical about their work performance when they were interrupted at work due to caregiving. Our findings suggest that workplace training for supervisors should include a component focused on how to deal with employees who have caregiving responsibilities. When employers and supervisors understand the circumstances surrounding employees’ caregiving responsibilities at an early stage, they may be able to diminish the adverse effects of work interruptions by providing caregivers with resources in advance (Mennino et al., 2005). In so doing, supportive employers and supervisors may be able to help employees with caregiving responsibilities to find ways of accommodating their work situations so that they can better balance their work and eldercare responsibilities and lessen the negative effects of work interruptions on work performance. In addition, this kind of support can make it possible for employers to retain employed caregivers in the long term and reduce management and administrative costs related to hiring new employees (MetLife Mature Market Institute & National Alliance for Caregiving, 2006). It may be that informal support at work, such as family supportive employers, benefits not only employed caregivers but also the employers.

Despite the important findings described above, our research is subject to several limitations. One limitation is that our analyses are based on cross-sectional data. Longitudinal research would allow for a clearer picture of causal relationships, and a more careful exploration of the relationships over time among eldercare responsibilities, caregivers’ stress, work interruptions, and work performance. Future research should examine the long-term impact of informal support from employers. It may be, for example, that when employers understand and provide support for their employees’ caregiving responsibilities in the short run, their employees’ work performance will actually increase over time, especially when caregiving responsibilities diminish.

In terms of measurement, our study also has some limitations. First, the measure of informal employer support was only a single item indicator. Although single item measures of informal support are not uncommon (Behson, 2005; Mennino et al., 2005), they may not tap into the multiple ways in which employers can be supportive. Follow-up research on informal employer support should use multi-item measures. Furthermore, one of the measures of work interruptions (i.e., “you missed too many days”) was not specifically related to eldercare. Future research should include eldercare-specific measures of work interruptions. In addition, this study relied on self-reported measures to conceptualize work interruptions and job performance. The respondents may have been reluctant to acknowledge the extent to which they actually experienced work interruptions related to their eldercare or they may have overrated their work performance. For this reason, it would be helpful for future research to incorporate measures of work interruptions and work performance that are provided by supervisors and employers.

Another limitation is that our model focused only on one source of support in the workplace; that is, informal support from an employer. Formal support such as flexible work policies, benefits, and services can diminish difficulties in balancing work and caregiving (Neal & Hammer, 2007) and may also influence work interruptions and performance. As the conceptual framework used in this study is further refined and tested, researchers should include formal as well as informal support in the model.

Last, it is important to note that this research was limited to employed caregivers of people aged 65 and above. In so doing, we excluded a large proportion of employees who cared for adults who were younger as well as those who cared for children with disabilities. We also did not consider variations in job type when examining the relationships among employer support, work interruptions, and work performance appraisal of employed caregivers. It is quite possible that the effects of supportive employers may vary by job type. For example, blue-collar employed caregivers may have different kinds of relationships with their employers and may interrupt their work in ways that differ from white-collar employed caregivers. Further research on employed caregivers should incorporate the broader population of caregivers and consider variations in the types of jobs that they hold.

In conclusion, this study contributes to a greater understanding of the dynamics that occur between caregiver stress and work performance. In particular, we highlight the role played by informal support from employers. As more employees are expected to have caregiving responsibilities in the near future, the role of a supportive employer is crucial in helping employed caregivers balance work and eldercare roles and in enhancing their work performance. Our findings point to the importance of helping employers and supervisors to understand and support employees’ eldercare situations. We urge other gerontological researchers to focus on the ways in which family friendly environments can influence employees who are balancing work and eldercare responsibilities.

fn.p: The author(s) disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: This research was supported by a National Institute on Aging (NIA) Fellowship (T32-AG000117).

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Jeungkun Kim, PhD, is a research fellow at the Samsung Economic Research Institute. His research interests include work and retirement, employed caregivers, and social welfare policy for older adults.

Berit Ingersoll-Dayton, PhD, is a professor at the University of Michigan School of Social Work and Director of the Joint Doctoral Program in Social Work and Social Science. Her research focuses on social support and clinical research with respect to families in later life.

Minyoung Kwak is a doctoral candidate in social work and sociology at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. Her research focuses on family caregiving for older adults and the relationship between the receipt of informal care and mental health among older adults.
